ERASED is a suspense/thriller wrapped in a character drama with elements of mystery sprinkled throughout.  That's a mouthful!  But it is this level of complexity that I believe elevates ERASED above a lot of other anime, and Tomohiko Itou really did a marvellous job directing this show into a wonderful adaptation.  Allow me to elaborate.
Too often of late in anime, studios are falling back onto fan-service pandering, questionably aged lolis, and read-the-manga endings to try and push more sales.  Rarely exists a show of a single cour that delivers one complete, self-contained story with an extremely satisfactory ending and with nocheap fan-service to boot!  ERASED delivers just that.  Reading the manga is an option for a bit of a different telling of the story, but isn't mandatory.  These reasons alone are enough to put ERASED above many, many other shows of late, but I'd like to delve through each rating category to see what I think it is that makes the show so compelling!


Story (10/10) - Right out of the gate, the story to ERASED is a fantastic one.  It is a mature, grounded story about a man unhappy with his own life and wanting to resolve past regrets that plague him even to this day.  Fortunately fate grants him that chance via the ability to travel back through time to his older self and relive pieces of his life in an attempt to change the future!  And this is how we begin our story: with our protagonist Satoru having just suffered a terrible loss and immediately sent back to when he was 11 years old, to a time when several girls at his school went missing.  He believes it is his job to save them to right past wrongs and hopefully change his terrible future!  Unfortunately his task is muddled as he doesn't know who the primary culprit is, so he instead races against the clock to try to save the children from their grim fate.  To make matters worse, the main female lead Kayo, one of the targets of this child murderer, is severely abused by her parents making protecting her a rather difficult task.  It is a very human story in the middle of this suspense thriller, and it does a fantastic job connecting you to the characters and pulling at your heart strings.  It makes you care when they are in danger, and really ratchets up the tension in ominous moments.  You get to follow Satoru on this harrowing journey, praying every step of the way that he makes it through.  It builds up to a couple huge and very heartfelt climaxes at the end of the show, and then an extremely satisfying finale that ties up all the loose ends.  It really is a great story that pulls you in, leaving you stressed one moment and ecstatic the next!


Art (9/10) - The art in this show is quite good.  It isn't the best ever, but it is consistently high quality.  I never noticed any severe drops in quality, and there was never a point where anything was unclear to the viewer.  The character designs are quite interesting and a bit different than what I'm used to seeing, especially with some adults like Satoru's mother, Sachiko.  They do a marvellous job of making the children adorable.  The art is also cleverly used to convey a lot of symbolism throughout the show, and you really have to pay attention to notice all the clever details packed into the art/animation!  Colours and contrast are used to the fullest to deliver a subtle messages to the viewer and influence their emotions as necessary.


Sound (8/10) - The sound in this show is also very well done.  There isn't a lot of complexity to it, but the OP/ED are both highly enjoyable to listen to, and the insert tracks throughout the show cue up perfectly at the exact moments required to really punch up the tension of a scene, or melt your heart with joy.  The VA work wasn't the best I've ever heard, but it was quite good.  I also appreciate the newcomer Shinnosuke Mitsushima voicing Satoru in an attempt to make him different and stand out from the rest of the show.  The director was clearly trying to stuff in as much symbolism as he could in ever facet of the show.  Kayo's VA and Sachiko's were both excellent and I enjoyed them every time they were on the screen.


Characters (10/10) - The characters of this show are absolutely fantastic.  The only real negative I can apply to this category is that the villain of the show is a little bit underdeveloped, but the direction they went with said villain is acceptable in my eyes as he is logically motivated and fleshed out enough to make the story interesting.  He doesn't need a deep backstory, as this isn't about the villain, this is a story about the protagonists and their plight.  The rest of the main cast were absolutely fantastic though.  Satoru was convincing as a super-hero wannabe, Kayo was beautifully developed and her unfortunate abuse really hit home for me, and Sachiko has got to win some awards for best mom in anime.  There's also the great supporting cast of all of Satoru's friends that help him along the way that get adequate screen time and do a great job supporting the main cast and letting them grow, while still managing to grow a little bit themselves!  I could connect and relate to a lot of the characters in this, with their thoughts often mirroring my own as I watched, and I absolutely adored Kayo and Airi every time they were on the screen.  One of the easiest 10/10s I could give, the characters were by far the highlight of this show.


Enjoyment (10/10) - This show was absolutely one of my favourite things to watch of the 2016 Winter season, and probably one of the most enjoyable shows I've seen to date.  The human element resonated deeply with me, the suspense had me on the edge of my seat, even when I could have sworn I just KNEW the answer, and the ending was tied up absolutely perfectly for my liking.  I got to see people grow, I got to see tragedy, I got to see victory, I got to see a mature story told without pandering fluff.  I adored every second of this show, even in spite some of the minor flaws with it, and I would gladly rewatch this again in the future, preferably with a dub so I can try and catch all the subtle details I missed on the first pass!


Overall: 10/10


By now I think you realize I loved ERASED.  It really is a fantastic show.  I think everyone owes it to themselves to watch ERASED at least once, or to at least give it a try before writing it off at face-value.  You may be surprised at how such a simple story can be so engaging.  Like Shirobako, it will be a staple recommendation for me to others.  The characters are just great, and the ending let me walk away with a smile on my face, regardless of the outcomes of all the characters and what was lost, because what was gained was so much more.  Rarely do I get to enjoy such a complete and satisfying experience from an anime, let alone one I think good enough to show to even non-anime fans, but ERASED is definitely one of them.  Props to A-1 for delivering such a fantastic experience, I value every second of it!

A manga artist with a special ability
to go back in time when a death occurs
became the victim of a kidnapper's hostility
needed to make their deaths deferred
Save his mother, and his friends
travel back to 1988
solve the mystery; make the amends
he alone will decide their fate.
“Pretending to smile, pretending to worry... I don't think that's a bad thing” - Kayo Hinazuki (ERASED, 2011)
At last, behold the anime that has climbed its way to the top of the rankings of MyAnimeList within the first few episodes; it comes as surprise to many veterans of anime whom have long searched for a series worthy of becoming the successor toSteins; Gate’s legacy. Boku dake ga Inai Machi, also known as “ERASED,” tells the tale of a dark yet heartwarming story that is sure to keep you awake cuddling underneath your blankets.


Story (10/10): ERASED is set near the present in which our main character, 29 year old Satoru Fujinuma possesses a supernatural ability forces him to go back into time, triggering whenever something bad happens. The fact that he is a struggling manga author is hardly relevant to the story at hand but may be explained in detail later. Satoru is involved in an incident which forces him to go back into time, all the way to 1988, where he must solve a murder mystery in order to change the future. He must uncover the details of the murder of a girl in grade school.


That girl’s name was Kayo Hinazuki.


ERASED is noticeably different from Steins; Gate, in the aspect that the former is part of the science fiction genre, while the latter is supernatural. The plot of ERASED is superbly written, and the pacing is perfect, each episode packed full of action and each ending leaving you craving for the next episode. In fact, it’s formatted so perfectly that I almost couldn’t resist reading the manga just to solve the mystery for myself. This anime is shown from Satoru’s point of view, and the balance of active dialogue along with narrative is a perfect mix as well, keeping viewers interested yet not in the dark about our main character’s thought processes. 


In a similar sense Steins; Gate, both plots begin in the same way with a death, which creates a sense of urgency and dread for the viewers. This really allows the people watching this anime to connect with the characters on a much deeper scale. ERASED also deals with other darker issues, including child abuse. This anime is one of the few out there making social commentary on issues most wouldn’t even consider thinking about; it has really enlightened me and made me think more about issues brought up. It is worth mentioning that Satoru's "Revival" ability isn't quite explained fully and does tend to gravitate towards being used as a plot device, but this could be overlooked. 


Character (9/10): In terms of character design, the characters all look very original. The art style and coloring fit the anime’s darker mood as well, and the characters are not so “moe” that it takes away from the realism aspect. Each character also has many different outfits, as expected from A-1 Pictures. As the setting is a school setting (for the most part), most of the time they are wearing student uniforms, which is expected. The background scenes are very well drawn and animated, as well as the character animation. 


Music (8/10):The soundtrack for the anime is amazing as well. The great variety of BGM empowers each scene, whether it's a sad or a catastrophic scene. Each of the tracks appeals to any number of human emotions and adds to the atmosphere of the story and scenes.


The opening sequence consists of young Satoru and his friends doing random things at his school. Almost everything is animated and isn’t taken from any scenes from any actual episodes, so A-1 Pictures definitely put in the effort weren’t lazy. Same with the ending. The opening “Re:Re:” by ASIAN KUNG-FU GENERATION is decent but not something insanely good like “My Dearest” from Guilty Crown. The ending, “Sore wa Chiisana Hikari no Youna,” by Sayuri fits the theme of the anime better and also sounds decent.


Voice Actors (9/10):What really impressed me the most was the voice actors. ERASED features a cast of well-known and experienced actors in the industry as well as two new voice actors making their debut: Mitsushima Shinnosuke and Tsuchiya Tao really impressed me even though it was their first time voice acting for an anime. On the other hand, Taichi You and Takayama Minami, who both possess massive talent and experience were able to bring to life their characters and really make this anime a pleasure to watch and listen to.


Character Development (8/10): At the beginning of the anime, even though Satoru has the "mind of an adult" and the body of a child, he still thinks he can solve everything himself, which is very childish thinking. However, progressively he learns to trust his friends and work together to find success. Hinazuki also opens up to Satoru more and more as the story progresses. Other than those two characters, there isn't much development for the other characters yet. Will be updated at end.


ERASED brings to life a dark and mysterious thriller that will definitely keep you on your toes. It’s execution of the plot is superb and art, animation, characters and music makes it definitely worth watching. Definitely, in my opinion, the best anime of the Winter 2016 season and could even be a top contender for best anime of the 2016 year.

Why I believe so many people were disappointed by Boku Dake ga Inai Machi/ERASED, and why I liked it: Review
Warning: Spoilers ahead
When Bokumachi started off, it was quickly hailed as one of the most promising animes of the season. It bravely covered topics like child abuse, kidnapping and time travel; it had a mature and non-generic lead character and seemed to generally target an older audience. Besides, who doesn’t love a good mystery?
I admit that I was a little hesitant about the first episodes. While I admired the show for challenging topics like child abuse and not being afraid to portray a darker take onwhat was, aside from the time traveling, meant to be a pretty realistic story, I did not particularly like its symbolism. Symbolism gets its strength from being subtle, from being discovered rather than being seen. The viewer is meant to be left wondering about the metaphors, interpreting them in his/her/their own way. But Erased was just too obvious with its symbolism, most of the time. We get it, a blue butterfly is meant to hint at the butterfly effect, which is in turn meant to hint at time traveling (seriously how many times have I seen this before?). We get that Hinazuki is abused. We get that she has bruises, you don’t need a black and white scene for me to notice how awful they are. We know Hinazuki’s mom is capable of doing horrible things. We know the teacher is suspicious without his face being covered in shadow. Often, I felt like the series was just throwing everything into my face, assuming I was too slow to notice otherwise. 


It disappointed me a little, because at other times, I thought the series did symbolism magnificently. Like the fact that Satoru’s voice actor was someone with next to no experience (and sounded like it), while the rest of the cast had pretty experienced voice actors. It felt like a little nod at the show’s title - The Town Where Only I am Missing. Or the red eyes, which were not only noticeable among the antagonists, but also among protagonists, like Satoru and Kenya. Why were Kenya’s eyes red when he was talking to the teacher? We don’t know for sure, and that’s what symbolism is all about: creating your own hypotheses.


Still, I really enjoyed watching this show. I think a lot of people were left disappointed because they had expectations that the show never intended to meet. It took me a couple of episodes to realize this. When I started watching, I was really excited about figuring out who the culprit was. I love a good whodunit, and I already had a list of suspects from the first episode on. However, it quickly became clear to me that this show did not want to be a whodunit. I began to wonder why the series wasn’t making the teacher less suspicious. In a kidnapping/child murder mystery, the teacher is often the culprit. There is no way the creators weren’t aware of that. That’s when I realized the show was not trying to hide the fact that the teacher was suspicious. Quite the opposite: they wanted us to find out who the culprit was, as soon as possible. His eyes would be red, his face would be hidden in shadows, he would look at the kids in a certain way, and the person who killed Satoru’s mom did not fit any other profile than the teacher’s. Because what the show was truly about, was not finding out who was the culprit. 


I may be wrong, but I believe this series, through all of its chaotic plots twists, from time traveling to child abuse to homicide to police investigations, was trying to give us an underlying message. Throughout all of the episodes, you have to keep the title in mind. I’ll repeat it for you: “The Town Where Only I am missing.” Satoru never really fit in, no matter which time arc he traveled to. In his own time, Satoru had been a failed manga artist, trying to make some extra cash by delivering pizza. He had next to no friends or interests, or memories he cherished. When he traveled back in time, he obviously did not fit in, with his 29 year mind in a 10 year old’s body. His friends, especially the clever ones like Kenya, were quick to catch up on this. Satoru himself noticed too that he was out of place, like when he experienced feelings of caring for Hinazuki (in a purely friendly way, I believe) which just didn’t seem right for a 29 year old man to have. Back in his own time arc, he was suspected of being a criminal. In this arc too, people didn’t really know him for who he really was. Where could he fit in? Which arc would make him the happiest? It was clear that Satoru had to create a town in which he would belong. And the only way to do that, was to bond with others. 

If I were to summarize the series’ message, it would be something like “A hero is not just one person; it’s multiple people working together.” Because what would Satoru have been able to do without his mom’s bold intuition? Or without Kenya’s cleverness? Or Hiro’s ability to notice people who didn’t fit in? 

That brings me to another subject I loved about this show. The show made a point about how “the weak” ones are the most likely targets of people with bad intentions. But weak does not always mean weak in a stereotypical way. Weak here meant: those who are alone, those who don’t have anyone else standing up for them, those who cannot talk to anyone else, those who come home to an empty house. The way Satoru and his friends defeated the teacher, was not through any sly method. It was through the best way a 10 year old kid could do things: by befriending whoever was alone. I really, sincerely loved that message. 


I’d like to end this with a last point that I loved about this show. When I said that Satoru did not fit in in any time arc, I wasn’t exactly right. If you’ve watched the show, you may have noticed that there is one thread that is represented in every time arc: Satoru’s mom. She is, in my opinion, the single most important character in the series. When Satoru would come across as “ a different person” to his friends or to Hinazuki, when he would even lose touch with his own identity - being a 29 year old in a 10 year old body- his mom would remind him that he was still her son. No matter which time arc he was in, his mom would always accept him for who he was. She knew him through and through. He was his mom’s son, no matter where he went, and that helped to keep his sense of identity. This was beautifully exemplified when, when Satoru truly went missing from his town - by being in a coma for years-  his mom kept taking care of him, as if he wasn’t missing, but had been there all the time. 

(Yeah I have a lot of feelings about Satoru’s mom.) 


So, in hindsight, I thought this was a really heart-warming anime that I enjoyed watching. A little pretentious by the end, not always as deep as it wanted to be (like Airi’s disappointing lack of character depth) and maybe with a few plot holes and unanswered questions (I still wonder why Hiro was targeted since he was a boy… was he just an alibi for the teacher?).

But I will forgive those things, because it did have some unique, beautiful moments. I would still recommend it to others. 

There is, however, not a doubt in my mind that the manga is better. I think I will read it.

Time travel isn't anything new to anime. We've seen it done again, and again, and again. Sure, some stories really throw a curveball into a mind-blowing plot, while others bite the dust of overused concepts. Every single episode of Erased is a cliff hanger. You want to know what's going to happen next every single time. It isn't your typical "better go back in time and save some friends" story. It really has it's own personal twist on it. The characters are easy to fall for, the main characters especially over the lesser important ones. While there's little relationship between Satoru and the 2 differentgirls that the viewers would like to ship them with, the story is really heartwarming and mature. There are many different layers to it. When you think you've figured out what will happen next, you're thrown in a completely different direction. The art for the most part is really enjoyable, and the sound is clear. This is a fantastic anime that I'd recommend to anyone looking for a new favorite. I don't see why the reviews are so mixed between low and high, but this definitely gets a 10 on my list. The few nitty gritty details don't knock it down to a 9.

EraseD SUCKS!!!!!!!!11!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!111!111111!!1!1/10 thanks for reading my re:review
……………… … … … 
are they gone yet…?
The Town Where Only I Am Missing (the name that actually has context) is actually a great anime in several places, so much that it partially makes up for the places where it isn’t great. Partially. Its biggest strengths lie in its “show, not tell” approach and emotional storytelling, but things start to go south when the story has completed its main arc and needs to shift gears. The first eight episodes would be a solid 8-9/10 with the last four being about a 5-6/10. Ultimately, it doesn’t handle its supernatural and(arguably) mystery elements very well, so if those are what drew you here, you’re gonna have a bad time.


The star of the show is Fujinuma Satoru, an incredibly deadbeat 29-year-old pizza driver with no friends and only one hobby that he sucks at, so he’s good as far as being a character for the audience to project themselves to goes. He has a supernatural ability called ‘butterfly;effect’, officially named “Revival”, where time jumps back a few moments and only he remembers, and this apparently happens whenever something bad happens and it’s somehow his job to save it, ‘cuz why not. But when the only person close to him is murdered and he’s framed as the suspect, he has a massive Revival that sets his life eighteen years back, just before the start of a kidnapping series that an old friend was wrongly convicted for.


And thus, the emotional rollercoaster begins. But, you know how rollercoasters work, right? They usually start off slow so they can build up enough height for the drops to actually work. Erased starts off pretty slow, and I’ll admit that it took me a couple episodes to be interested beyond the level of “What’s gonna happen from here?” But episode three was incredible for its intense drama and tear-jerking finale. I mean, I may be a misanthropic basement-dweller with no ambitions whatsoever, but for fuck’s sake, I still have feelings, you know? Erased, with its big emotional moments, wipes away all that hate for some time and makes me not want the 10-year-olds to get brutally sawed in half by a rake. Except that one girl from the lunch money incident. Yo, fuck that kid. No pedo.


Anyway, where was I? Oh yeah, the good writing.


Erased has a great way of showing us what we need to know, instead of just telling us. Instead of saying “Kayo is abused, feel bad!” we see it, but without getting gratuitous about it. Instead of hearing “This is making a big difference on Kayo’s life!” we see her responses and recognize the changes ourselves. Little things like these are what I appreciate, but it doesn’t feel too subtle and doesn’t require you to think hard about what’s going on. We see everything we need to know at just the right amount. ...Except for the things that aren’t shown at all, but we’ll get into that. 


So, what else did I like? Well, Satoru and Kayo, the two main characters, have great chemistry together that starts off a little awkward, ‘cuz Kayo’s like some socially inept punching bag and Satoru is a 29-year-old stuck inside a 10-year-old’s body. No pedo. But as Satoru makes it his life’s goal to protect Kayo (because Pokemon didn’t exist in 1988, what a harsh world), he grows attached to her and Kayo opens up to him and to those around her. It’s taken a little further because 29-year-old Satoru surprises himself as he occasionally says things in the moment, perhaps being more like his 10-year-old self instead.


Overall, the story is pretty good, but it falls apart after about eight episodes. The arc comes to a close, but there’s still a lot of ground to cover, and it’s clear that it needed to hurry in order to squeeze everything in the 12-episode limitation. What made this anime so good from the beginning were its incredible character moments, but daddy’s love is gone after the main arc is completed, as it’s clear that not much effort was put into the characters and plot that came afterwards. We get the new kid and a small plot to save them and not a single fuck was given that day. Anyone wanna go play Dragon Quest?


During these last episodes, the killer is finally revealed. Except it’s like the most obvious reveal ever. Like, if you didn’t figure it out at least an episode before then… you… might be… re……spected as a normal human being who simply processes things differently than me. The thing is, this was kinda labeled as a mystery series, but there wasn’t really any mystery. It’s disappointing because there’s another character that actually seemed sketchy to me. In the short time we see him, I thought that, just maybe, it wasn’t gonna be what ended up being the totally obvious. Unfortunately, they chose not to go down that avenue, and so we only get one legitimate suspect. You can’t play Clue with one character. However, all that being the case, I did actually enjoy the eventual reveal. I thought that, even if the show didn’t really try to hide it, they made this big bang pretty interesting.


While this certain villain is an interesting one, their motives were just… confusing. Something about a short story and seeing themself and their actions as the character to this story, something like that… Well, I did understand the concept, anyway, but like, WHY? Why are this person’s actions being driven by some made-up tale for children? It’s incredibly vague. I couldn’t connect with it.


Something also happens along with the villain’s reveal. It’s a spoiler so I won’t say what it is, but there’s no explanation of how it was resolved at all. It happens, and we’re just forced to accept the result even though there’s nothing in between to make sense of it. You’ll know it when you get to it.


The last thing that bothered me was Revival, Satoru’s time-travelling ability. It is NEVER explained how this works. Whenever I say these sorts of things, people say “oh fenne-kun~, yer so cynical, it’s like, totally beyond our knowledge, y’know??? it’s like God, it can’t be explained main, just accept it!!” Yeah, but here’s the thing. God is still defined to some extent and affects many people. You can’t just allow a supernatural phenomenon to affect one single person and expect everyone to go with it. That’s bullshit. Revival affects Satoru only (idc if this will later be given to someone else through the upcoming spin-off or whatever, what matters are these twelve episodes that are supposed to tell a complete story) and goes away when the story is over. The entire plot literally depends on Revival, because without Revival then Satoru wouldn’t go back to 1988, he’d still be a boring pizza guy who makes shit manga, and we wouldn’t have the story itself. It’s too important to shrug off.


Now, Revival doesn’t exactly have to be explained. I CAN interpret it as something that transcends our world and our knowledge of it. But, if anything, the villain should’ve had the same ability. SOMEONE should’ve had the same ability. This should not have been excluded to Satoru only, it is way too convenient. I like to compare and contrast Revival with The Force from Star Wars. It’s not explained (phantom menace literally does not exist), but it’s there, and many people (or… things) have it. It’s incredibly surreal and mysterious, but it’s central to the series’ lore. Something like that would’ve been a good inspiration for Erased.


The main character is a bit of a controversial one. Satoru is, again, a 29-year-old now who spends most of the show trapped inside a 10-year-old’s body. No pedo. And so, his personalities conflict with one another and get confusing. The moments when his 29-year-old mind will ask himself questions are the best, but they’re too infrequent. It’s good that he has a little self-awareness, it’s just that he doesn’t have enough self-awareness. It’s like his first day on the job as a color commentator for a sport he knows nothing about. But, looking back, his dual personalities were the only interesting thing about him. Look at either of them individually and see that there’s not much to look at in the first place. But… is that so wrong? Really? I won’t defend him as an interesting character, but I don’t think it’s totally fair to judge a deadbeat 29-year-old loser for being a 29-year-old loser, or for thinking an ordinary 10-year-old kid is an ordinary 10-year-old kid.


Kayo, on the other hand, has a much more defined personality due to her bitchy mother being a bitch to her. She’s closed off and even cold to others, but she opens and warms up to not only Satoru, but anyone else around her as she finally learns how to live. You see a really positive and satisfying change to her. No pedo. Beyond development, the character herself is interesting anyway, since she’s much more thoughtful and will sometimes say some interesting things, like her characteristic “Are you stupid?”. 


There are two supporting characters all fulfill their roles greatly. Kenya is one of Satoru’s classmates. He’s mature and intelligent for his age and is not only helpful to Satoru, but can detect that something is wrong. Not what is wrong, just that something is, and it’s probably beyond him. He knows his place. Good kid. No pedo. Sachiko, Satoru’s mom, not only has some hot MILF lips, but is well-written in just a couple simple ways. She gets killed, right? But instead of hyping her up to be truly deserving of a coffee mug that says “WORLD’S BEST MOM”, she’s killed instantly without us getting to know her, but they later build her character up to be very likable so that we hope Satoru succeeds in reversing the future killings. Also, she’s just a good motherly character, which is important in the context of Erased, where one of the biggest plot threads involves Kayo getting abused by her mother. She’s basically the foil to this antagonist. Or… it’s the other way around… i failed ap english okay


There’s also Airi, a supporting character in the present time… While she had some real p-u-n-c-h at times, I thought she was a little too convenient? Like, she only showed up when the story absolutely needed someone to help Satoru out. Maybe that’s just me, but I didn’t really care for her. She at least had her reasons, though. Don’t steal chocolate bars, kids.


There are some other characters, of course, namely Satoru’s other friends, but they’re not needed so their lack of depth is okay. They’re just along for the ride.


The OP of Erased is actually really, really good. I didn’t care for it much at first, but it grew on me quickly, and I think I’ll be getting into the band Asian Kung-Fu Generation soon. The song has a very moderate-paced alternative rock sound characterized by some highs and lows after the first verse. The lack of any electronic or string accompaniment makes it feel more natural, and in a way, more human. It’s pretty fitting to the theme of the anime, and the animation supporting it is nothing short of acceptable. The ED holds its own as well with its gentle, but heartfelt feel that later ascends into a powerful, grand song about… whatever. I don’t actually know what it’s about. Whoops. Anyway, while I was never crazy for this theme, the full version played over the last episode was absolutely stunning. Shut up, kid, lemme play my air guitar.


The rest of the soundtrack ranges from decent to good; it’s evidently an emotional one and sets the tone very well, but it has a tendency to reuse certain pieces a little too often. The voice acting is nothing special, but it gets the job done; many characters sound casual, as they should. Satoru himself has an incredibly deadbeat voice, and sometimes I think it’s a little TOO monotonous; I get that he’s a boring dude, but for fuck’s sake, man, lighten up a little. You’re a kid again. Everyone else is okay.


Visually, Erased is a bit of an oddity for its wide, theatrical aspect ratio during its time in the 80’s. For modern scenes, you’re getting a typical ratio. This was a good move and somehow added to the drama of the past. It also contains some pretty good camera shots and not-so-subtle symbolism which aren’t groundbreaking by any means, but are also welcome additions. The art itself is pleasant with some good, but also casual environments complemented by some good lighting and some passable character designs that probably won’t stand out on their own through time, but this isn’t supposed to be some wild, crazy fantasy. One common complaint is that A-1 Pictures makes extremely similar-looking characters in most of their anime, but Erased is an exception to this. Congrats, you guys. You actually did something right for about two seconds, and then Grimgar happened. But that’s for another review...


All this said, I enjoyed Erased for the most part. I don’t want the final four episodes to completely muddy the excitement of the first eight. (That includes the chocolate bar incident. Yes, I am okay with that story. It seems perfectly plausible to me.) I even felt… a little content with the overall ending. It wasn’t horrible, even if the events leading up to it were rushed. But the ending was at least mostly satisfying. No pedo.


Erased is simply a good show with some really noticeable bruises. Just like Kayo.

ERASED is the most tragic kind of failure to witness. To put it simply, it is an anime full of ideas that it doesn’t know how to use. Forging an engaging premise with many mysteries that are yet to unfold, the ideas it had initially presented are suddenly shoved under the rug, only to be pulled back out when convenient, as if they were nothing more than a mere afterthought. And so without the support it needs, the story loses its way and tumbles down into an abyss of mediocrity. There is nothing more saddening to me than the failure of something that could havebeen excellent if handled some other way.


For a show that comes off as a mystery anime, not much mystery is to be found here. After such a meticulous build up to what would be an exciting murder mystery thriller full of mind games and plot twists, ERASED doesn’t make good use of this. The show suddenly shifts its main focus from the murder mystery tale onto how Satoru will get Kayo rescued, and stays that way throughout the majority of the show, leaving all other aspects of the plot underdeveloped and unexplored. With the amount of mysteries from the beginning, little to no progress is made from there. Satoru rarely considers coming closer to the mystery or making any kind of plan, for he is unable to get Kayo off of his mind. He doesn’t come in contact with any of the suspected individuals nor does he suspect anything along the way. In the end, Satoru confronts the killer through nothing but convenience, making the payoff measly at best. I never felt involved in the mystery up to this point and I was given little to think about. To make matters worse, the identity of the killer is so thinly veiled it’s downright insulting. If you think you’ve guessed the identity of the killer by the third episode, trust me, you guessed correctly. And the show continues to make it more and more obvious to the point where you might as well ditch the mystery entirely. This kind of thing would have worked if the show was intending to mislead the viewer through this method, but assuming this was the case would be giving the writer and the director too much credit.


And now on to the time traveling aspect. Time travel has always been a risky choice when it come to writing stories, due to how difficult it can be to handle. But nonetheless, the “Revival” power beheld by Satoru is an interesting story element that makes way for possibilities. Sadly, this power turns out to be little more than a convenient way of getting Satoru in and out of certain situations, and is neither experimented with nor fleshed out beyond that. In writing, any consequences spawned from the use of time travel is the least of the show’s concern when ERASED doesn’t even bother to take any kind of risk with it. On top of this, the rules on how it operates are unclear, and it only seems to activate whenever convenient for the plot. At first it activates when a tragedy occurs, but then it activates based on Satoru’s emotions. Not only does this create more holes than a colander, it eliminates any kind of tension taking place in the story, which is the biggest kick in the nuts for a thriller. Without the necessary knowledge for any possible outcome, I’m unable to feel any kind of investment. The Revival power is yet another aspect with could have delivered if only the story knew what the hell it was doing.


There are plenty more elements of the story that the show refuses to take advantage of. Jun Shiratori is a close friend of Satoru’s who was falsely suspected prior to the main plot, and yet we don’t ever hear of him again. We are given info on Satoru’s career as a mangaka, and yet it contributes absolutely nothing to the plot. The core plot of ERASED feels so disconnected from the initial premise, that it might as well be only written as a simple story of a child’s mission to rescue his abused classmate. Satoru doesn’t act like a 29-year-old as he should, the Revival power has little involvement in this plot, there is nothing thought provoking about the mystery, and numerous other elements stick out like a sore thumb.


The plot with Kayo Hinazuki wouldn’t be as much of an issue if it held some merit to warrant being the main focus. But this sadly isn’t the case. Kayo is not a bad character, but she isn’t a very interesting one either. She is little more than an ordinary child who suffers from abuse, and is yet to be murdered. Her development is scarce throughout the story. For these reasons, this particular plot would be better off being little more than a few episodes long, which would also clear some room for the mystery and the Revival power to be tampered with. In addition, her parental abuse gets an unnecessary amount of focus, in spite of how insubstantial it really is. Kayo has no psychological struggle we can relate to other than simply needing friends. ERASED fails to realize that the negative effects of parental abuse extend far beyond being lonesome. When a subject such as child abuse gets as much focus as it gets here, I expect it to be fleshed a whole lot more than a mere concept of emotional appeal.


To make matters worse, Satoru is incompetent as hell when it comes to protecting someone, let alone solving mysteries. He never plans things out, and instead dives headfirst into any situation in front of him, never thinking about anything that might go wrong. Why not take a picture of the evidence of Kayo’s abuse when you see it? Why not put a lock the RV you're keeping her in? Why does he try to perform a sneak attack on Kayo’s mother instead of...I dunno...spying on her? Disregarding how bland of a character Satoru is, it’s difficult for me to root for him when he doesn’t even have the thought process of a human being.


It’s worth mentioning that ERASED tries its darndest to have empathy given to any character, whether they be an ally, or a villain. Even the most heinous acts, whether they be child abuse or a murdering spree, is given a motive to show that these characters were actually good people who just did some bad things. But little insight is given to their psychology or their character, and so I remain disconnected, and unable to believe these backstories contribute to any theme or story element other than superficial empathy from the viewer.


ERASED does have strengths. As little meaning as the interactions between Satoru and Kayo hold, they are certainly entertaining to watch. With Satoru being timid and Kayo being composed and dominant, the moments between these characters are most certainly the strongest aspect of ERASED. It gives some life to the story and as such is the main selling point of the show.


The cast of characters in ERASED ranges from being a mixed bag to forgettable overall. Satoru’s introverted nature serves little to the story and his personality isn’t fleshed out beyond a simple good-moraled hero. And yet again, it’s a damn shame his career as a mangaka turned out pointless. Kayo is little more than a plot device whose arc is unworthy of having so much time spent on. The cheerful personality of Anri perhaps serves as a light in Satoru’s dark night sky, so to speak. Too bad that her involvement in the plot or effect on Satoru’s character is minimal. Satoru’s mother is the bomb. She is easily likeable due to having a sense of ration along with her being sincere and practical, as well as being an awesome mother. She is a good character, even if she doesn’t really develop. Every other character is either defined by only their struggles, or is just a blank slate. While some are entertaining on a surface level, pretty much all of them are as bland as a rice cracker in terms of character dimensions. Drama is forged through victimizing rather than actual relatable, human struggles.


Moving on to the visual aspect, it’s rather hit-or-miss. Not necessarily in terms of how it looks, but by how it conveys things. It’s generally a good-looking show overall. The backgrounds are rather lovely and the animation is fluid enough. The character designs, although generic, are very appealing and are well-fit for the characters’ personalities. The directing, however, is handled like a child. Suspenseful and emotional moments are so ham-fisted and over-the-top it’s almost laughable. When I have pretty much gotten the point of what a scene is trying to convey, the directing then takes extra steps to make full certainty that I understand, which only serves to hurt more than help. An example is how inhumanly spastic Kayo’s abusive mother behaves. As far as I’m concerned this isn’t how abusive parents really act. The directing also overuses stylization with its use of color and obvious symbolism, which is often borderline immersion-breaking. Any character with a feeling of malicious intent will be given red eyes, because apparently the viewers are too incompetent to get the point otherwise. On the other hand, the 1988 sequences are given a nice atmosphere to them, making it easy to feel involved in each scene. So while the director seems to be headed in the right direction, he has not proven to be skillful enough based on what we find here.


ERASED is not a bad show. It has its moments, and some deal of entertainment can be found. But the end result of what it was initially hyped up to be is nothing short of a disappointment. With no idea of what it wants to be, clumping numerous underdeveloped plot elements together, along with irrational behavior of the characters, and what we’re left with is a Frankenstein’s monster of a storyline. It is easy to say that the premise of ERASED had overpowered the writing, and would have turned out better if it had been handled by a different author entirely.
